prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: helms34
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe redshifted [CII]158um, OH163um, and continuum in a single spectral setup at high spatial resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The lines in this source are broad, approaching 900km/s to zero intensity (approximately 1400km/s for the OH doublet feature). We also aim to detect the continuum, and thus request the maximum available bandwidth. Line-free spw are placed adjacent to the line spw's to recover any possible broad wings due to outflows that may not be detected in existing CO data. The spw containing the OH line is slightly shifted off the line center to allow for a valid spectral setup, but the adjacent spw will recover any potential extended line wing if necessary. To allow for optimized velocity binnings based on the dectected dynamical structure, we ask for higher spectral resolution than available in TDM mode (which is too limiting), but we bin spectrally by a factor of 4 to keep data rates at a reasonable level.

The source is ~1.0"x0.6" in diameter based on ALMA CO observations. The LAS is likely much smaller than 1", but we here conservatively assume this as a limit. At the redshift of the source, 0.094" (C36-6 configuration) corresponds to a resolution of 600pc, which is the most suitable for our science goals seeking approximately half a kiloparsec resolution. At this resolution, the source is ~70 beams across (in units of pi*r_source^2/pi*r_beam^2). Accounting for potential faint, tidal structure (source appearance may indicate a few kpc separation merger), we conservatively assume a size of 80 beams total for our sensitivity estimates. We further note that our estimates are conservative, since the source will likely not fill all beams in smaller velocity bin, such that the actual S/N per beam per velocity bin will likely by at least 7-10 in practice.

The total estimated [CII] line peak flux is 183mJy (estimated based on CO/[CII] and [CII]/FIR luminosity ratios observed for similar sources at similar redshifts; e.g., Cox et al. 2011; Riechers et al. 2013, 2014) at an FWHM of 468km/s (same as CO), which we here assume to be resolved over 80 beams, resulting in 2.3mJy/beam. The continuum flux is 55mJy, i.e., 0.69mJy/beam if resolved over the same area. The resulting required spectral dynamic range of a factor of ~5 is only modest, and thus, expected to be unproblematic. The expected average S/N ratio of the spatially resolved line emission is 18 over the entire bandwidth, i.e., it will be possible to retain a S/N ratio of >5 when resolving the line over >12 spectral bins across the FWHM. We expect the OH line to be 40% as bright as the [CII] line (based on recent detections in similar galaxies at z=5-6; Riechers et al. 2013, 2014), at almost twice the line width (OH is a doublet). We thus expect to detect the line at S/N>7 per beam over the full width of the line.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: xmm30
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe redshifted [CII]158um, OH163um, and continuum in a single spectral setup at high spatial resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The lines in this source are broad, approaching 900km/s to zero intensity (approximately 1400km/s for the OH doublet feature). We also aim to detect the continuum, and thus request the maximum available bandwidth. Line-free spw are placed adjacent to the line spw's to recover any possible broad wings due to outflows that may not be detected in existing CO data. The spw containing the OH line is slightly shifted off-center to allow for a valid frequency configuration, but any possible extended line wing will be covered by the adjacent spw if necessary. To allow for optimized velocity binnings based on the dectected dynamical structure, we ask for higher spectral resolution than available in TDM mode (which is too limiting), but we bin spectrally by a factor of 4 to keep data rates at a reasonable level.

The source is ~1.0"x0.4" in diameter based on ALMA CO observations. The LAS is likely much smaller than 1", but we here conservatively assume this as a limit. At the redshift of the source, 0.092" (C36-6 configuration) corresponds to a resolution of 580pc, which is the most suitable for our science goals seeking approximately half a kiloparsec resolution. At this resolution, the source is ~50 beams across (in units of pi*r_source^2/pi*r_beam^2), which we assume for our sensitivity estimates. We further note that our estimates are conservative, since the source will likely not fill all beams in smaller velocity bin, such that the actual S/N per beam per velocity bin will likely by at least 7-10 in practice.

The total estimated [CII] line peak flux is 68mJy (estimated based on CO/[CII] and [CII]/FIR luminosity ratios observed for similar sources at similar redshifts; e.g., Cox et al. 2011; Riechers et al. 2013, 2014) at an FWHM of 486km/s (same as CO), which we here assume to be resolved over 50 beams, resulting in 1.4mJy/beam. The continuum flux is 45mJy, i.e., 0.9mJy/beam if resolved over the same area. The resulting required spectral dynamic range of a factor of ~7 is only modest, and thus, expected to be unproblematic. The expected average S/N ratio of the spatially resolved line emission is 11 over the entire bandwidth, i.e., it will be possible to retain a S/N ratio of >5 when resolving the line over ~4-5 spectral bins across the FWHM. We expect the OH line to be 40% as bright as the [CII] line (based on recent detections in similar galaxies at z=5-6; Riechers et al. 2013, 2014), at almost twice the line width (OH is a doublet). We thus expect to detect the line at S/N>4.5 per beam over the full width of the line.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: sgp38326
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe redshifted [CII]158um, OH163um, and continuum in a single spectral setup at high spatial resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The lines in this source are broad, approaching 1400km/s to zero intensity (approximately 1900km/s for the OH doublet feature). We also aim to detect the continuum, and thus request the maximum available bandwidth. Line-free spw are placed adjacent to the line spw's to recover any possible broad wings due to outflows that may not be detected in existing CO data. The spw containing the OH line is slightly shifted off the line center to allow for a valid spectral setup, but the adjacent spw will recover any potential extended line wing if necessary. To allow for optimized velocity binnings based on the dectected dynamical structure, we ask for higher spectral resolution than available in TDM mode (which is too limiting), but we bin spectrally by a factor of 4 to keep data rates at a reasonable level.

The source is <1" in diameter based on ALMA CO observations. The LAS is likely much smaller than 1", but we here conservatively assume this as a limit. We here assume that the source is of order 4kpc (0.5"-0.6") across, as typically found for bright dusty star-forming galaxies. At the redshift of the source, 0.078" (C36-6 configuration) corresponds to a resolution of 530pc, which is the most suitable for our science goals seeking approximately half a kiloparsec resolution. At this resolution, the source then is ~50 beams across (in units of pi*r_source^2/pi*r_beam^2). We further note that our estimates are conservative, since the source will likely not fill all beams in smaller velocity bin, such that the actual S/N per beam per velocity bin will likely by at least 7-10 in practice.

The total estimated [CII] line peak flux is 40mJy (estimated based on CO/[CII] and [CII]/FIR luminosity ratios observed for similar sources at similar redshifts; e.g., Cox et al. 2011; Riechers et al. 2013, 2014) at an FWHM of 752km/s (same as CO), which we here assume to be resolved over 50 beams, resulting in 0.8mJy/beam. The continuum flux is 31mJy, i.e., 0.62mJy/beam if resolved over the same area. The resulting required spectral dynamic range of a factor of ~6 is only modest, and thus, expected to be unproblematic. The expected average S/N ratio of the spatially resolved line emission is ~8 over the entire bandwidth, i.e., it will be possible to retain a S/N ratio of >5 when resolving the line over >2-3 spectral bins across the FWHM. We expect the OH line to be 40% as bright as the [CII] line (based on recent detections in similar galaxies at z=5-6; Riechers et al. 2013, 2014), at almost twice the line width (OH is a doublet). We thus expect to detect the line at S/N>3 per beam over the full width of the line (OH is a secondary science goal; sensitivity requirements are set by the [CII] line).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: sgp54107
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe redshifted [CII]158um, OH163um, and continuum in a single spectral setup at high spatial resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The lines in this source are broad, approaching 1600km/s to zero intensity (approximately 2100km/s for the OH doublet feature). We also aim to detect the continuum, and thus request the maximum available bandwidth. Line-free spw are placed adjacent to the line spw's to recover any possible broad wings due to outflows that may not be detected in existing CO data. The spw containing the OH line is slightly shifted off the line center to allow for a valid spectral setup, but the adjacent spw will recover any potential extended line wing if necessary. To allow for optimized velocity binnings based on the dectected dynamical structure, we ask for higher spectral resolution than available in TDM mode (which is too limiting), but we bin spectrally by a factor of 4 to keep data rates at a reasonable level.

The source is <1" in diameter based on ALMA CO observations. The LAS is likely much smaller than 1", but we here conservatively assume this as a limit. We here assume that the source is of order 4kpc (0.5"-0.6") across, as typically found for bright dusty star-forming galaxies. At the redshift of the source, 0.075" (C36-6 configuration) corresponds to a resolution of 520pc, which is the most suitable for our science goals seeking approximately half a kiloparsec resolution. At this resolution, the source then is ~50 beams across (in units of pi*r_source^2/pi*r_beam^2). We further note that our estimates are conservative, since the source will likely not fill all beams in smaller velocity bin, such that the actual S/N per beam per velocity bin will likely by at least 7-10 in practice.

The total estimated [CII] line peak flux is 60mJy (estimated based on CO/[CII] and [CII]/FIR luminosity ratios observed for similar sources at similar redshifts; e.g., Cox et al. 2011; Riechers et al. 2013, 2014) at an FWHM of 891km/s (same as CO), which we here assume to be resolved over 50 beams, resulting in 1.2mJy/beam. The continuum flux is 57mJy, i.e., 1.15mJy/beam if resolved over the same area. The resulting required spectral dynamic range of a factor of ~1 is only modest, and thus, expected to be unproblematic. The expected average S/N ratio of the spatially resolved line emission is 10 over the entire bandwidth, i.e., it will be possible to retain a S/N ratio of >5 when resolving the line over >4 spectral bins across the FWHM. We expect the OH line to be 40% as bright as the [CII] line (based on recent detections in similar galaxies at z=5-6; Riechers et al. 2013, 2014), at almost twice the line width (OH is a doublet). We thus expect to detect the line at S/N>4 per beam over the full width of the line (OH is a secondary science goal; sensitivity requirements are set by the [CII] line).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Dusty star-forming galaxies (DSFGs) at high redshift are thought to be dominantly highly dissipative mergers of gas-rich galaxies that represent extreme, short-lived starbursts. This picture is supported by studies of gas dynamics, but unfortunately, the resolution of past studies remained limited to 3-4 kpc even for the best handful of cases (with only a single exception), which is barely adequate to resolve the galaxies. Through a novel selection technique based on Herschel/SPIRE colors, we have identified a new sample of DSFGs at z=4.16-6.34. Using the new long baselines of ALMA, we propose to study the [CII] gas dynamics, OH and dust in 4 representative z=4.2-5.2 starbursts in our sample down to 500pc resolution. Based on dynamical models, we will investigate the occurence rate of major mergers vs. disks, measure dynamical masses, and constrain the physical properties of individual gas clumps down to physical scales not previously accessible outside the local universe. We will also search for faint, "CO-dark", perhaps low-metallicity companion galaxies within 100-150kpc of our massive, dusty starbursts. This comprehensive investigation will remain unrivaled for years to come.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
